1. Meteorological and hydrological monitoring network is operationalized in the Polog region as a basis for the future floods 2. Priority ecosystem-based flood risk mitigation measures are conceptualized and designed providing basis for their future implementation 3. Preparation of the national-level flood risk mitigation strategy and action is launched 4. Possibilities for advancing the risk financing and risk transfer options are explored and implementation priorities of the project are defined

1. The early warning system is being established in cooperation with the Hydro-meteorological Service (HMS), the emergency response agencies (Crisis Management Center and the Protection and Rescue Directorate), and the Polog municipalities as the key constituents of the system. The project supported in-depth analysis of the status of existing hydro-meteorological monitoring vis-à-vis the actual needs. The expert findings suggest full re-activation and an upgrade of the monitoring system by applying phased approach, so as to give the responsible institutions time to adapt to the increased demand for operation and maintenance. The approach is tailored based on consultations with the national monitoring authorities , taking into consideration their current capacities and future development plans. New monitoring stations will be used to upgarde the existing system that was re-activated as part of an earlier UNDP-backed project. Activities for providing the necessary technology (e.g., monitoring stations and software) are underway. In the upcoming period, the project will concentrate on installation and start of operation of the improved hydrological and meteorological monitoring system, along with capacity development assistance targeting HMS. This monitoring system, along with improved weather forecast capacity will be the key elements of a basin-scale flash-flood early warning and public-alert system. In parallel to efforts to upgrade the monitoring system, the project will work on developing and testing protocols that will encompass all measures that need to be undertaken when a warning is given for a potentially harmful flood event. The system will be co-designed through the involvement of the affected communities to identify a workable localized solution and avoid all possible barriers to effective response to potential crisis situations.
2. The risk-based prioritization of torrential flooding for the entire Upper Vardar River Basin carried out as part of FRMP enabled the project to make more informed investment decisions for mitigation actions. Based on the FRMP, as a subsequent stage, for the highest priority torrential streams, the project will commission a comprehensive feasibility study that will help conceptualize and compare different mitigation options. A detailed technical documentation on the selected options will provide more accurate estimates on investments needs that will help the project focus on priorities that can fit into available budget from different sources. As part of this activity, the project will support more mature interventions for which there is significant interests among the local communities and/or major political will (e.g., torrents in the villages of Shipkovica that was hit by the 2015 floods which also caused loss of human lives). Such interventions will serve as demonstration projects, and will help maintain high interest in the project, and improve resource mobilization prospects. Regarding landslides, the project will support stabilization of priority landslides as demonstration projects. Priority will be placed on multi-purpose alternatives such as the stabilization of the particularly active landslide above the village of Bozovce, Municipality of Tetovo. A separate detailed study will propose and prioritize measures to reduce the risk of landslides (e.g., through physical interventions, and improved planning) and will provide guidelines for construction and infrastructure which will reduce the costs of living with landslides. Additionally, the FRMP revealed that the Basin is facing with a highest annual forest cover loss rate at national level of nearly 5% (app. 50 hectares of forest in a single year). Project strategy is to reduce pressures on the forest cover and accelerate its regeneration through: a) reduced demand for firewood through energy efficiency measures; b) afforestation and re-forestation of priority erosive land; and c) improved enforcement of regulations against illegal logging.
3. The national-level flood risk mitigation strategy is being conceptualized and its launching is postponed for 2019. This will give UNDP time to ensure full complementarity of other ongoing and planned relevant projects funded by other donors (e.g., EU). Such adaptation of the implementation schedule will ensure better use of resources by avoiding duplication, as well as creating additional synergies.
4. The project has established initial cooperation with the authorities, and financial institutions on introducing different financing instruments to improve risk management. The focus on this early-stage cooperation has been on generating knowledge and exploring possibilities for joining efforts to reduce long-term risks to people and property from floods and facilitate post-disaster recovery efforts through improved financing. The cooperation with the Ministry of Finance and the Insurance Supervision Agency is promising and opens possibility significant positive influence on the financing side of DRR. The project will place emphasis on conceptualizing and facilitating the introduction of long-term risk financing and risk transfer mechanisms at national, regional (e.g., river basin), and local (e.g., municipal) levels. For this purpose, the project will carry out a comprehensive gap analysis targeting existing financial capacities and instruments vis-à-vis the actual needs based on the improved knowledge about country’s overall flood risk situation. The purpose of this work will be to enable strategizing future risk mitigation investments through increased public expenditures in flood prevention, justifying a cost-effective use of increasingly scarce financial resources. Moreover, on the basis of the comprehensive risk assessments, and understanding mitigation potentials and limitations (i.e. residual risk), the project will support the national stakeholders to carry out comprehensive study into the insurance market development potentials. As part of this work, the project will consider a full possibility of financial mechanisms for prevention, post-disaster response and risk transfer, aiming to improve the overall ability of institutions, businesses and communities to respond more resiliently to disastrous flood events in future. The project is also attempting to take full stock of the comprehensive analytical work and general recommendations of other ongoing Swiss-funded regional initiatives in the design and implementation of specific project activities.
